column4: hi, i'm currently installing a piece of software, and the instructions tell me to run the commands: cd dir-to-software; ./configure --prefix=/instdir --sysconfdir=/instdir/conf;  make; # but it said to run the commands as a specific user (it told me to create the user earlier in the install instructions).  i accidentally ran these commands as root instead.  my questions are a) what do these commands actually do?  does ./configure do
from which its run?
in other words, if i simply delete the directory from which i ran these commands, will my system be in an identical state as it would be if i had never downloaded/installed the software?
probably not.
did you make install?
how can i entirely "undo" these commands?
its a rather obscure piece of software
did you run `make install'?
which software?
its called evergreen, library management system
no, only 'make'
is /install there?
rather, is there a /install in your system?
do you mean is there a file called install in my root directory?
yes
if you ran the configure just like that...
no, there's not any file called /install
it probably didn't install anything then.
why would u think there'd be a file called /install?
I guess insdir rather.  You had said you typed in: './configure --prefix=/instdir --sysconfdir=/instdir/conf;  make;'
yes, exactly
